thread.title: Bilibid drugs case: Ex-BuCor OIC Ragos surrenders to NBI
thread.title_full: Bilibid drugs case: Ex-BuCor OIC Ragos surrenders to NBI

author: Rappler.com
title: Bilibid drugs case: Ex-BuCor OIC Ragos surrenders to NBI
text:
Philippines Bilibid drugs case: Ex-BuCor OIC Ragos surrenders to NBI (UPDATED) Ex-Bureau of Corrections OIC Rafael Ragos said he 'delivered' drug money to Sen. Leila de Lima when she was still Justice Secretary Published 11:44 AM, February 26, 2017 Updated 12:47 PM, February 26, 2017 In this file photo, former Bureau of Corrections officer-in-charge Rafael Ragos testifies at the House Committee on Justice inquiry on the alleged drug trade at the New Bilibid Prison, September 20, 2016. Photo by LeAnne Jazul/Rappler 
MANILA, Philippines (UPDATED) – Rafael Ragos, the former Bureau of Corrections (BuCor) officer-in-charge who is one of the co-accused in the case of illegal drugs trade inside the New Bilibid Prison, has surrendered to the National Bureau of Investigation (NBI) on Sunday, February 26. 
Ragos is one of the co-accused in one of the drug cases filed by the DOJ February 17, the latest development of a 5-month high-profile investigation of the supposed drug trade inside the national penitentiary in Muntinlupa. 
Ragos arrived at the NBI before noon Sunday, NBI Deputy Dante Gierran said. 
At the forefront of the cases is Senator Leila de Lima, who is accused of having links to the drug lords detained in Bilibid. 
During one of the House committee hearings on the issue, Ragos testified that he personally delivered millions of pesos in drug money to De Lima's residence, back when she was still justice secretary. (READ: Bilibid probe witnesses: We delivered P5-M ‘quota’ to De Lima ) 
Aside from De Lima and Ragos, the others charged before the Muntinlupa RTC were the senator's ex-driver and boyfriend Ronnie Dayan, former BuCor chief Franklin Jesus Bucayu, Bucayu's former staff Wilfredo Elli, inmate Jaybee Sebastian, De Lima's ex-security aide Joenel Sanchez, and Jad de Vera. 
The DOJ filed 3 criminal complaints before the court against De Lima, accusing her of violating Section 5 of the Dangerous Drugs Act, which penalizes the "sale, trading, administration, dispensation, delivery, distribution and transportation of illegal drugs." 
Violators face 12 years to life imprisonment and fines range from P500,000 to P10 million. 
An arrest warrant was issued for De Lima, Ragos, and Dayan, on Thursday, February 23, less than a week after the charges were filed. The warrant was issued by Judge Juanita Guerrero of the Muntinlupa Regional Trial Court branch 204. 
Dayan was arrested in Urbiztondo, Pangasinan on Thursday, while De Lima surrendered to authorities on Friday. 
Ragos will be in NBI custody until a committment order is issued by the RTC, which will indicate where he will be jailed. – Rappler.com HOW DOES THIS STORY MAKE YOU FEEL? Happy
